30 of each year, commencing on September 30, 2024. The 2029 Notes will mature on March 31, 2029. The 2031 Notes will mature on March 31, 2031.

The Issuer may redeem all or part of the 2029 Notes on or after March 31, 2026, at the redemption prices set out in this offering memorandum. Prior to
March 31, 2026, the Issuer may redeem, at its option, all or part of the 2029 Notes at a redemption price equal to 100% of the principal amount thereof, plus accrued
and unpaid interest and Additional Amounts (as defined herein), if any, plus the Applicable Premium (as defined herein). In addition, prior to March 31, 2026, the
Issuer may also redeem at its option up to 35% of the original principal amount of the 2029 Notes (including the original principal amount of any Additional 2029
Notes) with the net cash proceeds from certain equity offerings at a redemption price equal to % plus accrued and unpaid interest, if any, provided that at
least 65% of the original principal amount of the 2029 Notes (including the original principal amount of any Additional 2029 Notes) remains outstanding after the
redemption date. The Issuer may redeem all or part of the 2031 Notes on or after March 31, 2027, at the redemption prices set out in this offering memorandum.
Prior to March 31, 2027, the Issuer may redeem, at its option, all or part of the 2031 Notes at a redemption price equal to 100% of the principal amount thereof,
_plus accrued and unpaid interest and Additional Amounts, if any, plus the Applicable Premium. In addition, prior to March 31, 2027, the Issuer may also redeem at_
its option up to 35% of the original principal amount of the 2031 Notes (including the original principal amount of any Additional 2031 Notes) with the net cash
proceeds from certain equity offerings at a redemption price equal to % plus accrued and unpaid interest, if any, provided that at least 65% of the original
principal amount of the 2031 Notes (including the original principal amount of any Additional 2031 Notes) remains outstanding after the redemption date. Upon
the occurrence of certain events constituting a change of control, the Issuer may be required to make an offer to repurchase all of the Notes at a redemption price
equal to 101% of the principal amount thereof, plus accrued and unpaid interest and Additional Amounts, if any. In the event of certain developments affecting
taxation, we may redeem all, but not less than all, of the Notes.

The Notes will be governed by German law and will constitute senior obligations of the Issuer. The Notes and all obligations under the Senior Secured Facilities
Agreements (each as defined herein) are, and the Notes will be, secured by first-ranking liens over the Collateral (as defined below) (although any liabilities in
respect of obligations under certain potential future Super Senior Credit Facilities (as defined in the Intercreditor Agreement) as well as Priority Hedging Obligations
and Cash Management Liabilities (each as defined herein) that are secured by the Collateral will receive priority over the Notes and obligations under the Senior
Secured Facilities Agreements with respect to any proceeds received upon any enforcement action over the Collateral). The Notes and all obligations under the
Senior Secured Facilities Agreements will rank pari passu among themselves and equal in right of payment with all existing and future obligations of the Issuer
that are not subordinated in right of payment to the Notes and obligations under the Senior Secured Facilities Agreements, will be effectively subordinated to all
existing and future indebtedness of the Issuer that is secured by property and assets that do not secure the Notes and obligations under the Senior Secured Facilities
Agreements, to the extent of the value of the property and assets securing such indebtedness, will rank senior in right of payment to any existing and future
indebtedness of the Issuer that is subordinated in right of payment to the Notes and obligations under the Senior Secured Facilities Agreements, and will be
structurally subordinated to all existing and future indebtedness of the subsidiaries of the Issuer that are not Guarantors (as defined below).

The Notes will be guaranteed (the “Guarantees”) on a senior basis by certain subsidiaries of the Issuer (the “Guarantors”). The Guarantors also guarantee the
Senior Secured Facilities Agreements on a pari passu basis. The Notes and all obligations under the Senior Secured Facilities Agreements are, and the Notes will
be, secured by first-ranking liens over (i) the shares of the Issuer, Progroup Board S.A.S. and each Guarantor; (ii) certain real property; (iii) certain bank accounts
of the Issuer; and (iv) certain fixed and other assets (the “Collateral”) as described in more detail under “Description of the Notes—General—Security; Release of
_Collateral”. The Guarantees and the security interests over the Collateral will be subject to certain significant contractual and legal limitations or subject to certain_
defenses under applicable law. See “Certain Insolvency Law Considerations and Limitations on the Validity and Enforceability of the Guarantees and Security

**Non-GAAP Financial Measures**

In this offering memorandum, we present certain non-GAAP measures and ratios, including Total Output, Gross Profit,
EBITDA, EBITDA Margin, Trade Working Capital, Free Cash Flow, Change in Total Working Capital, Core Operating
Cash Generation, Cash Conversion, Capital Expenditures, Total Liabilities, Total Financial Debt, Net Financial Debt,
Contribution Margin as well as other pro forma data, including Pro Forma Senior Secured Debt, Pro Forma Senior Secured
Net Debt, Ratio of Pro Forma Senior Secured Debt to EBITDA and Ratio of Pro Forma Senior Secured Net Debt to
EBITDA to reflect certain effects of the Refinancing as if such Refinancing had occurred in (i) January 1, 2024, for purposes
of the calculation of income statement and cash flow items or (ii) December 31, 2023, for purposes of the calculation of
balance sheet items, that are not required by, or presented in accordance with, German GAAP.

We define “Total Output” as the sum of sales, increase/(decrease) in finished goods and work in process, other own work
capitalized and other operating income.


-----

We define “Gross Profit” as Total Output minus cost of materials.

We define “EBITDA” as sales, _plus increase/(decrease) in finished goods and work in process,_ _plus other own work_
capitalized, _plus other operating income,_ _minus cost of materials,_ _minus personnel expenses,_ _minus other operating_
expenses, plus net extraordinary expenses/(income) and minus other taxes.

We define “EBITDA Margin” as EBITDA divided by sales.

We define “Trade Working Capital” as inventories plus trade receivables, minus trade payables.

We define “Free Cash Flow” as cash flow from operating activities plus cash flows from investing activities.

We define “Change in Total Working Capital” as (increase)/decrease in inventories, trade receivables and other assets
_plus increase/(decrease) in trade payables and other liabilities between the respective periods as presented in the_
Consolidated Cash Flow Statement.

We define “Core Operating Cash Generation” as as EBITDA minus Change in Total Working Capital.

We define “Cash Conversion” as Core Operating Cash Generation as a percentage of EBITDA.

We define “Capital Expenditures” as additions to tangible fixed assets plus additions to intangible fixed assets.

We define “Total Liabilities” as investment grants for fixed assets, plus provisions, plus liabilities, plus deferred income
_plus deferred tax libailities._

We define “Total Financial Debt” as bank loans _plus bonds,_ _minus other securities (i.e., Existing Notes we have_
repurchased and hold on balance sheet).

We define “Net Financial Debt” as Total Financial Debt minus cash-in-hand, bank balances.

We define “Contribution Margin” as sales, plus increase/(decrease) in finished goods and work in process, minus cost of
materials, minus freight expenses.

Our management believes that the presentation of these non-GAAP measures is helpful to investors because these and
other similar measures are widely used by certain investors, security analysts and other interested parties as supplemental
measures of performance and liquidity, among others.

We believe that EBITDA, EBITDA Margin and Cash Conversion are widely used by investors to measure our operating
performance and are useful metrics for evaluation of our operating performance and are useful metrics for evaluation of
our performance as they facilitate comparisons of our core operating results from period to period. In addition, we believe
Cash Conversion is useful as an indicator of our ability to convert EBITDA into available cash. EBITDA, EBITDA Margin
and Cash Conversion can vary substantially from company to company depending on the accounting methods, book value
of assets and capital structure or method by which assets were acquired. EBITDA eliminates potential differences in
performance caused by variations in capital structures (affecting net interest income/expense), tax positions (such as the
availability of net operating losses against which to relieve taxable profits), and by the cost and age of tangible assets
(affecting the relative depreciation expense) and the extent to which intangible assets are identifiable (affecting relative
amortization expense).

We present Free Cash Flow because we believe this measure is useful to investors to understand the funds that we have
available before we have met our financial obligations.

We present Core Operating Cash Generation as a proxy for our ability to generate cash flow from our core operating
activities.

We present Capital Expenditures as we believe it is useful to assist investors to assess our investing activities.

However, you should not construe these non-GAAP measures as an alternative to net income or other items of our
Consolidated Income Statement determined in accordance with German GAAP, to cash flows from operating activities,
investing activities or financing activities or to liabilities or other balance sheet items of our Consolidated Balance Sheet.
In addition, these non-GAAP measures and ratios presented by us may not be comparable to similarly titled measures used
by other companies and may have limitations as analytical tool. These non-GAAP measures have been provided for
informational purposes only and are not indicative of historical results, cash flows or liabilities nor are they meant to be
predictive of future results, cash flows or liabilities. Moreover, we have calculated, reconciled and presented certain of


-----

these non-GAAP measures, including in particular, Core Operating Cash Generation, by mathematically adding and/or
subtracting line items from our Consolidated Income Statement, Consolidated Cash Flow Statements and Consolidated
Balance Sheet, which, in each case, has not been prepared in compliance with the requirements under Regulation S-X
under the U.S. Securities Act or the Prospectus Regulation or the SEC or any other regulator. Investors are therefore put
on notice to treat these non-GAAP measures with caution.

**OUR COMPANY**

We are a leading, family-owned producer and supplier of containerboard and corrugated board in Central Europe and are
headquartered in Landau, Germany. According to Vision Hunters, we are the third largest producer of corrugated board in
Europe (by production capacity) through our corrugated board business (“Board”) and the fifth largest producer of recycled
containerboard in Europe (by production capacity) through our containerboard business (“Paper”). We focus on the highly
efficient production and processing of standardized grades and customized small batch series of corrugated board sheets
for our mostly family-owned box manufacturing customers. In this core market segment, we are the market leader by
volumes sold in Germany, Austria, Belgium, the Czech Republic, Poland and the Netherlands, according to Vision Hunters,
and following significant recent and ongoing investments, we have also been becoming a significant market player in Italy
and the United Kingdom. We believe we differentiate ourselves from other market participants (i.e., fully integrated paper
and packaging producers) through our strategic focus on those elements of the value chain that bring added-value to our
customers in the packaging industry, i.e., the automated and integrated production of containerboard and corrugated board.
Our customers serve various end markets, including industrial/manufacturing, consumer durables, processed foods, nonfood manufactured consumer goods and fresh food. Unlike many fully integrated market players, we do not produce boxes
and therefore do not compete with our box manufacturing customers but instead focus solely on the production of
containerboard and corrugated board. We are part of the circular economy as the end products made with our corrugated
board and containerboard can serve as raw materials in our business after use by the end customer. In addition, we thermally
utilize foreign materials present in the recovered paper we use as a our main raw material as well as production residues
from our paper manufacturing processes in our waste-to-energy plant. This enables us to generate the steam required for
paper production at PM2 as well as a portion of our electricity requirements ourselves. In our paper mills, we almost
exclusively use recovered paper as a raw material for the production of containerboard. We use containerboard made from
recovered paper as much as possible in our corrugated board formats. This enables us to reduce the use of virgin fiber paper
(kraftliner) and thereby the amount of virgin pulp used in the production of our corrugated board.

Through our large scale and highly flexible production, built up primarily via a greenfield approach and, more recently,
via packaging park projects, we are able to realize significant economies of scale. Since we commenced operations in 1992,
we have carefully selected the locations of our production sites and have grown organically by pursuing primarily a
greenfield strategy to create an optimal geographic set-up of our production sites across the markets in which we operate.
As a result, we believe we benefit from a well-invested asset base and production sites with high technological standards,
resulting in a relatively low cost base compared to many of our competitors and relatively low requirements for additional
capital expenditures in the short- to medium-term. Given the high technological standards of our production facilities, we
believe we are well-positioned to benefit from major growth trends in our industry, such as (i) increasing demand for light

**OUR STRENGTHS**

We believe we benefit from the following competitive strengths.

**Differentiated business model with leading market positions in attractive market environment**

Our founder and vice chairman of our Supervisory Board, Jürgen Heindl, designed a business model differentiating us
from our competitors. Through our strategic value chain positioning in containerboard and corrugated board production
only, we do not compete with our targeted customers, who are primarily family-owned, small- and medium-sized
businesses. Our core customers focus on packaging solutions for the end-customer and typically do not have their own
corrugated board production capability. Many of our competitors are fully integrated and focus on serving larger endcustomers in large batch sizes, including global consumer corporates. Our differentiated business model allows us to serve
a higher number of customers, process a higher number of orders and maintain higher production volumes per production
site (up to 450 million square meters of corrugated board per annum), thereby generating economies of scale. We are solely
focused on the production process as opposed to many of our competitors, who also focus on more complex and customerspecific packaging requirements for a smaller number of larger customers and, hence, only have an average production
output of typically 80 to 90 million square meters per production site per annum.

In 32 years since our foundation, we have achieved leading market positions in the countries in which we operate. We are
among the top three corrugated board producers in Europe (by production capacity) and our market share in our specific
segment, the corrugated sheet market in Europe, was approximately 19% according to February 2024 market research by
Vision Hunters. In our core market segment, namely corrugated board sheets, we were the market leader by volumes sold
in Germany, Austria, Belgium, the Czech Republic, Poland and the Netherlands, according to Vision Hunters, and we hold
considerably higher market shares in those markets compared to our position in the overall European containerboard and
corrugated board market. In Germany, we have been further expanding our leading market position in recent years with (i)
the start of production at a new corrugated board plant (PW13) in Eisfeld, Germany, with an annual corrugated board
production capacity of approximately 135,000 tons, in November 2019, (ii) the start of production at our third and newest
paper machine (PM3) in Sandersdorf-Brehna, Germany, with an annual capacity of approximately 750,000 tons of
containerboard, in August 2020, (iii) the ongoing construction of a new corrugated board “mega plant” (PW15) in
Petersberg, Germany, with an expected annual corrugated board production capacity of approximately 200,000 tons and
test production expected to commence in the first half of 2024, as a packaging park project right next door to our longstanding customer and partner G&G Preißer, and (iv) the start of construction of a new waste-to-energy plant (PPO2) at
the site of PM3 in Sandersdorf-Brehna, to supply our paper machine PM3 with the required process heat as well as
electricity.

We have also become market leader in the Polish market, following the start of production at our corrugated board
production site (PW10) in Trzcinica, Poland in 2017 and the start of commercial production in January 2023 and ongoing
ramp-up of our newest corrugated board “mega plant” (PW14), with an annual corrugated board production capacity of
approximately 200,000 tons, right next to our earlier corrugated board plant (PW7) in Strykow, Poland. Similarly, we have
also become a significant player in the UK market, following the commencement of production in January 2019 and
subsequent ramp-up at our corrugated board “mega plant” (PW12) in Ellesmere Port, United Kingdom, with an annual
corrugated board production capacity of approximately 200,000 tons, which replaced the much smaller and
decommissioned production site PW8. In addition, the commencement of production at our corrugated board production
site (PW11) in Drizzona, Italy in March 2018, with an annual corrugated board production capacity of approximately
135,000 tons, marked our entry into the largest corrugated sheet board market in Europe. We also commenced construction
of a further corrugated board “mega plant” (PW16) in Cessalto, Italy in the fourth quarter of 2023 and expect production
to commence at the new site in the first half of 2025. In the corrugated sheet market, we had a market share of approximately
19% in 2022 in Europe, according to the February 2024 market research by Vision Hunters.

While we believe our differentiated business model, high reliability and quality of product supply, significant scale, internal
sourcing and geographic coverage provide us with a competitive advantage in our core market segment, we also benefit
from attractive market fundamentals of the overall industry.

Over many years, the paper and packaging industry has experienced overall growing demand from industrial economies in
Central Europe, and we believe that Germany and Central Europe, our key markets, generally provide a positive economic
outlook. The last two years have been slightly negatively impacted by softness in containerboard and corrugated board
demand as well as destocking trends. However, structural growth trends such as rising urbanization, increasing demand for
convenience (i.e., take-aways and home deliveries) or sustainability awareness should drive the demand recovery expected
by RISI and Vision Hunters in the next 4 to 5 years, as mentioned under “Industry and Competition”. From a product
perspective, the increasing significance of light-weight paper and packaging solutions as well as small-size packaging and
the increasingly online and mail order-driven retail sector is expected to further stimulate packaging growth. We believe
our modern production facilities, particularly PM2, which is capable of producing light-weight paper grades economically
on a commercial scale, and PM3, which is one of world’s largest and most modern and high-performance paper mills,

position us well to benefit from these growth trends in the industry. Furthermore, production is driven by the strong increase

**Uniquely designed, best-in-class and strategically located, low-cost production asset base built up via greenfield**
**strategy**

Since our foundation in 1991, we have carefully designed and selected our production operations and locations via a
dedicated greenfield strategy to establish highly efficient, flexible and technologically advanced production facilities. We
believe we continue to be the fastest organically growing corrugated board producer in Europe and have developed a unique
track record and expertise in successfully establishing new greenfield corrugated board production sites. This includes a
dedicated and experienced in-house projects team tasked with identifying attractive market opportunities for profitable
growth, completing the planning and construction phases of the relevant projects on time and on budget and managing fast
and successful ramp-ups of production at the relevant sites.

Designing our production set-up primarily via a greenfield strategy allowed us to invest in the best available production
specifications and optimize the alignment and compatibility of our paper machines, PM1, PM2 and PM3, with our
corrugators. The current 2.5m, 2.8m and 3.3m trim widths of our various existing corrugated board plants can be very
efficiently combined with the 5.8m trim width of PM1 (2 × 2.8m or 2.5m + 3.3m), the 10.2m trim width of PM2 (4 × 2.5m
or 3 × 3.3m) and the 9.2m trim width of our newest paper machine PM3 (2 × 3.3m + 2.5m or 2 × 2.8m + 3.3m), resulting
in low volumes of cutting scrap and higher productivity.

Our corrugated board production sites have been purposefully located approximately 500 kilometers from each other. This
footprint ensures close customer proximity with full regional coverage of our customers and limited overlap to limit the
transportation distance in most circumstances to 250 to 300 kilometers. Our strategic footprint also allows us to achieve
high production flexibility and reliable just-in-time delivery with short lead times. Furthermore, we are able to serve our
customers from different locations, thereby optimizing transportation costs and capacity utilizations on a plant-by-plant
basis, which is coordinated centrally from our headquarters in Landau following a “one mill approach”. We believe our
location layout and organization give us a competitive advantage in terms of cost efficiency and customer orientation. On
average, we serve approximately 50 to 80 customers per corrugated board production site and each of our production sites
offers the entire range of customer services (e.g., 24 hour delivery and online ordering and tracking).

We believe that all of our plants are equipped with state-of-the-art technology, which is the foundation of our low-cost and
efficient production. According to Vision Hunters, the asset quality of our paper machines is characterized as high and
above comparable European containerboard and corrugated board producers. Performance metrics of PM1, such as
capacity and technical age, are well above the industry average. PM2, which we believe to be among the world’s most
advanced paper machines for recycled super-light-weight paper and which specializes in the production of super-lightweight to medium-weight containerboard with grammages of 60 to 130g/m[2], ranks best in class for all metrics and has set
six new world records since its launch in 2010. PM3 is not only one of the world’s most modern and high-performance
paper machines for manufacturing environmentally friendly and high-quality containerboard, but also one of the world’s
largest paper factories.

Unlike many of our competitors, who grew historically over many decades or had to integrate production infrastructures
inorganically through acquisitions, we differentiate ourselves through our well-invested asset base and high-quality,
complementary, modern and strictly aligned, high capacity production facilities placed purposefully in strategic locations.

We believe that our ability to provide reliable delivery of high-quality, cost-effective and tailor-made products and being
a family-owned business have enabled us to foster strong partnerships of mutual dependence with our mostly family-owned
customers, operating as a fundamental part of their supply chains by improving inventory management, security of supply
and customer service.

Our strong customer relationships are reinforced through a combination of our geographic reach, our manufacturing and
logistics excellence, and the limited availability of alternative suppliers with the capacity and geographic proximity to


-----

provide a competitive offering. At a number of our corrugated board production sites, certain long-standing customers have
established their own box manufacturing plants in immediate proximity to our site, either on our own land or on land

these two packaging park projects (PW09 and PW10), we also established our corrugated board production site (PW11) in
Drizzona, Italy as a packaging park project in immediate proximity to the existing packaging plant of our customer, Italian
packaging specialist Imbal Carton S.r.l., and we are currently constructing yet another new corrugated board plant (PW15)
in Petersberg, Germany, with test production expected to commence in the first half of 2024, right next door to our longstanding customer and partner G&G Preißer. The next corrugated board plant (PW16) in Cessalto, Italy, which is expected

All versions of the packaging park model help us to further strengthen our relationships with key customers or win
significant new customers (as in the case of Imbal Carton S.r.l. in 2018) and benefit both us and the relevant customers.
The high level of integration between our own corrugated board production and the box production of our customers
allowed by the packaging park model creates a number of efficiencies and largely eliminates freight and other freight
expenses between Board and our packaging park customers. This business model does not require pallets, simplifying the
delivery process. Our packaging park customers also typically purchase almost all of their corrugated board requirements
for the relevant box plant from us, which ensures predictable, high volume orders and consistently high utilization levels
for the relevant corrugated board production sites. Index pricing arrangements with our packaging park customers further
ensure a predictable pricing mechanism for all parties. It typically takes approximately two to three months for
containerboard mills to pass on their raw material price increases to their customers, _i.e.,_ manufacturers of corrugated
board. In turn, the manufacturers of corrugated board generally attempt to raise prices to recover containerboard cost
increases. It generally takes approximately two to three months for corrugated board manufacturers, including us, to pass
these increases on to their customers, although the extent and speed with which we are able to pass on cost increases to our
customers, if at all, can vary significantly, depending on prevailing market conditions.

**Sustainable Company in the Circular Economy**

Progroup’s products are shining examples of the circular economy. We only ever use recovered paper as the raw material
for our containerboard. The end product is also a recyclable product because at the end of its life the corrugated board is
largely processed through waste separation and reused throughout Europe. Our production processes also follow the
concept of a cycle: we produce energy from production residues and waste materials in our waste-to-energy plant in


-----

Eisenhüttenstadt, Germany. Our water loops are closed on two of our three paper machines, and we recycle corrugated
board rejects back into the production cycle as a raw material used for papermaking.

The process of producing containerboard uses a lot of water. In our paper mills, we utilize water not only in the production
process, for example for breaking down recovered paper, but also for cooling and cleaning the facilities. To reduce the
level of consumption, we operate closed water cycles on two of our three paper machines (PM1 in Burg and PM3 in
Sandersdorf-Brehna). This means that there is no wastewater from production on these two machines, and on PM3 waste
water only comes from ancillary systems alongside the paper machine. These technologies are unique in our industry. This
has enabled us in recent years to significantly reduce the amount of fresh water we require for each ton of total output.
Compared to 2012, the reduction by 2021 was around 37% and by 2022 was around 34%. This slight increase in the specific
water consumption is attributable primarily to the increased amount of water used at our combined heat and power plant
compared to the previous year. By 2030, we aim to achieve a reduction in the specific amount of fresh water per ton of
total output by 40%.

Climate neutrality is a major challenge for Progroup, as it is for many other manufacturing companies. In Germany, the
paper industry is one of the three most energy-intensive industries. Although less energy is required for producing
recovered paper than for fresh fiber paper, our company is still to a large degree energy-dependent. The final drying of the
containerboard is done using steam, whose production consumes a lot of energy. In 2022, our total emissions were at
roughly the same level as the previous year despite our growth. We also continuously optimise our facilities. This allows
us to utilise steam and heating energy more efficiently. At the same time, the most effective lever at present for reducing
costs and emissions is to operate waste-to energy plants. Using substitute fuels also allows us to reduce the amount of gas
we use. By 2025 we want to reduce our specific emissions – relative to our total output of containerboard and corrugated
board sheets – by 35%. By 2030 the new power plant in Sandersdorf-Brehna should help us to achieve a saving of 40%.

**OUR STRATEGY**

**Maintain and strengthen our position as a leading, low-cost corrugated board producer in Europe through**
**controlled investments**

To maintain and further strengthen our position as a leading, low-cost corrugated board producer in Europe in the longterm and to allow us to successfully meet expected future market growth and the requirements of our customers with regard
to supply certainty and product quality, we intend to continue to make prudent and controlled investments to further expand
and improve the efficiency of our production facilities as part of our long-term “Two Twentyfive” strategy, as long as
(i) we are confident we can achieve payback periods for our investments that are aligned with the maturity profile and
relevant headroom under our financing arrangements, (ii) we maintain sufficient financial flexibility to weather and/or
adapt to challenges that may face us or our industry as a whole, and (iii) any such investments would be consistent with
our long-term target leverage. In addition to further capacity expansion, our “Two Twentyfive” strategy, among other
things, also contemplates a gradual technological transition and generation change away from the use of corrugators with
a trim width of 2.5m, which are installed and currently in use at some of our older corrugated board production sites, to the
use of more modern corrugators with trim widths of 2.8m or 3.3m at most of our corrugated board production sites.


-----

With the start of production in August 2020 and subsequent ramp-up at our third and newest paper machine (PM3) in
Sandersdorf-Brehna, Germany, we became a significant net seller of containerboard again. In the short- to mid-term, we
therefore intend to continue to focus our investment activities on further expanding our corrugated board production
capacity to be able to seize what we believe are numerous further market opportunities for profitable growth, similar to
those that led to the successful establishment of six new corrugated board plants (PW09, PW10, PW11, PW12, PW13 and
PW14) in Plössberg (Germany), Trzcinica (Poland), Drizzona (Italy), Ellesmere Port (United Kingdom), Eisfeld
(Germany) and Strykow (Poland) since 2015. We expect that (i) the start of commercial production in January 2023 and
the ongoing ramp-up of our newest corrugated board “mega plant” (PW14) in Strykow, Poland, with an annual corrugated
board production capacity of approximately 200,000 tons, (ii) the expected start of test production in the first half of 2024
and subsequent ramp-up at our proposed corrugated board “mega plant” (PW15) in Petersberg, Germany, and (iii) our
further proposed corrugated board “mega plant” (PW16) in Cessalto, Italy alone will lead to a significant further increase
in the corrugated board production of Board, so that we expect to be operating again at the top end of our long-term target
corridor with regard to the level of integration between Paper and Board and again become a net purchaser of
containerboard in the mid-term. With the proposed additional corrugated board plants (PW15 and PW16) in Petersberg,
Germany and Cessalto, Italy, we expect our annual corrugated board production capacity to increase from currently
approximately 1,815,000 tons to approximately 2,215,000 tons.

In continuation of our organic growth strategy, we intend to achieve further growth by pursuing further expansion
opportunities via greenfield projects. However, as with our corrugated board production sites (PW03) in Burg, (PW05) in
Schüttorf, (PW06) in Offenbach a.d. Queich and (PW09) in Plössberg, Germany, our corrugated board production sites
(PW10) in Trzcinica and (PW14) in Strykow, Poland, our production site (PW11) in Drizzona, Italy and our production
site (PW12 ) in Ellesmere Port, United Kingdom, we are also establishing our proposed new corrugated board production
site (PW15) in Petersberg, Germany as a packaging park project in immediate proximity to the existing packaging plant of
one of our customers, German packaging specialist G&G Preißer, allowing us to supply that long-standing partner largely
without freight and other freight expenses. Our latest corrugated board project (PW16) in Cessalto, Italy will also be
established in immediate vicinity to an existing packaging customer as a packaging park.

While we have historically pursued a pure greenfield growth strategy, including in connection with the ten packaging park
projects (PW03, PW05, two packaging park customers at PW06, PW09, PW10, PW11, PW12, PW13 and PW14) and the
proposed new corrugated board production sites (PW15 and PW16) in Germany and Italy, we are also evaluating and will
continue to evaluate opportunities to find partners to leverage the benefits of a packaging park that would enrich our existing
network of production sites, advance our goal of further increasing our corrugated board production capacity and meet the
other internal investment and financing criteria described above. In addition, in order to maintain and/or strengthen our
relationships with certain large and long-standing customers or in response to opportunities to establish relationships with
significant new customers, we will consider additional packaging park projects whereby we would establish corrugated
board production sites at or in proximity to the packaging plants of the relevant customers. We currently expect to make
total investments of approximately €246 million into the two proposed new corrugated board production sites (PW15 and
PW16) in Germany and Italy. With an expected combined annual incremental corrugated board production capacity for
PW15 and PW16 of approximately 400,000 tons of corrugated board, an average net selling price per ton of corrugated
board of €756.1 per ton in 2023 and historic EBITDA margins for Board in the high single digit to low double digit range,
we believe PW15 and PW16 to be able to make a sizable contribution to EBITDA following completion of both projects.
Historically, our new corrugated board production sites have typically achieved a capacity utilization level of around 90%
within 3 to 5 years of start of operation.

In the first quarter of 2023, we also started construction of a new waste-to-energy plant (PPO2) next to PM3 in SandersdorfBrehna, to supply our newest paper machine with the required process steam as well as electricity. We currently expect to
make total investments of approximately €190 million, with a target completion date towards mid 2025.

**Maintain cost leadership through continuous efficiency and profitability improvements**

In order to maintain profitability throughout the economic cycle, we have been running a comprehensive profitability
improvement program for many years (the “Continuous Improvement Program”) to ensure the long-term success of our
Group. Our Continuous Improvement Program focuses on (i) improving the effectiveness of our sales and marketing
activities, (ii) optimizing (i.e., minimizing) our variable costs and (iii) stabilizing our specific fixed costs in order to achieve
sales excellence and maintain our position as one of the cost leaders in the recycled containerboard market. Since 2012,
our main focus in connection with our goal of achieving sales excellence has been on (i) growing our external sales in
excess of the general growth in market volumes (and thereby increasing our market share), (ii) maximizing the impact of
the introduction of our “next generation” products into the market and (iii) optimizing our sales portfolio. As part of our
efforts to optimize our variable costs, we have focused on (i) reducing our consumption of raw materials, (ii) optimizing
our energy consumption and energy costs (including as a result of the cost savings we believe to generate form the operation
of our new waste-to-energy plant (PPO2) next to PM3 in Sandersdorf-Brehna), and (iii) reducing the purchase prices of
our key production factors, such as recovered paper, starch and freight services. Overall, we have met or exceeded our


-----

targeted benefits through our Continuous Improvement Program. We intend to continue to implement our Continuous
Improvement Program and identify and realize further improvement opportunities.

**MARKET AND TRADING UPDATE**

**Market Update**

We experienced increasing volumes at the start of 2024, especially in Poland and the DACH region, a trend we expect to
continue throughout the first quarter of 2024. In addition, we see further potential for volume growth in the United
Kingdom.

The most recent information available to us from third party sources regarding operating rates in the European
containerboard industry also indicate an improvement in the first two months of 2024. At the same time, stock levels of
containerboard in the industry have been decreasing and were well below the values of the prior year.

After a small price decrease in the containerboard market in January, prices remained stable in February. We understand
that all major players in the European containerboard industry, including us, have announced price increases of
approximately €70 to €80 per ton for either March or April 2024. According to a containerboard price index, approximately
€50 to €60 per ton of these announced price increases have already been implemented in March 2024. We expect to pass
on these containerboard price increases to our corrugated board customers with the typical time lag.

**Trading Update**

Based on management accounts, our operating performance for the month of January 2024 showed a strong corrugated
board volume increase of 4.7% compared to January 2023, supported by (i) the successful and ongoing ramp-up following
the commencement of commercial production at our latest corrugated board “mega plant” (PW14) in Strykow, Poland in
January 2023, and (ii) increasing sales volumes in Italy and the United Kingdom. The volume of externally sold
containerboard also increased by 18.8% compared to the prior year period. Sales prices for both corrugated board and
containerboard further decreased compared to January 2023, which resulted in an approximately 19.5% decrease in sales
from approximately €140.4 million in January 2023 to approximately €113.0 million in January 2024. Our EBITDA
decreased from €31.8 million in January 2023 to approximately €12.8 million in January 2024.

**THE REFINANCING**

The “Refinancing” refers to the issuance of €750,000,000 aggregate principal amount of the Notes pursuant to the Offering
and the use of a portion of the proceeds from the Offering (i) to redeem in full the €600,000,000 outstanding principal
amount of the Existing Notes on or about       , 2024, and (ii) to pay costs, fees and expenses related to the Refinancing,
including underwriting fees and commissions, commitment, placement, financial advisory and other transaction costs and
professional fees.

We further expect to use a portion of the proceeds from the Offering to finance our proposed investments into the proposed
new corrugated board production sites (PW15 and PW16) in Germany and Italy, with a combined expected total annual
incremental corrugated board production capacity of 400,000 tons, and the proposed new waste-to-energy plant (PPO2)
next to PM3 in Sandersdorf-Brehna, Germany. For more details see“Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial
_Condition and Results of Operations—Key Factors Affecting our Results of Operations—Expansion Projects and_
_Investment Program”. You should also read “Use of Proceeds”, “Capitalization” and “Description of Other Indebtedness”_
for a more detailed description of the expected use of proceeds and our capitalization and financing arrangements following
the completion of the Refinancing.

_This offering memorandum also contains forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties. Our actual_
