**KEY FACTORS AFFECTING OUR RESULTS OF OPERATIONS**

We principally generate revenue through the sale of containerboard and corrugated board. We sell our corrugated board
only to third-party customers in the packaging industry. Our mills primarily supply the containerboard we produce to
Group-owned corrugated board plants; however, only third-party sales are reflected in our revenue. We also sell, to a lesser
degree, containerboard to third parties, and these third-party sales of containerboard have increased significantly in the
periods under review following the start-up and ongoing ramp-up of our newest paper machine (PM3) in SandersdorfBrehna, Germany in August 2020. In 2023, corrugated board sales and external containerboard sales accounted for 85.6%
and 12.6%, respectively, of our total sales.

Key factors that affect our operating results are:

  - changes in demand and industry production capacity;

  - the cost of recovered paper, other raw materials and other costs of manufacturing;

  - changes in energy costs, both as a result of market price movements and regulatory changes, including energy tax
refund schemes and other statutory accommodations for energy intensive industries;

  - changes in freight and transportation costs;

  - our ability to pass on price increases in raw materials and other input costs into the prices we charge for third-party
sales of containerboard and corrugated board;


-----

  - the performance and the utilization of our production sites as well as the performance of certain facilities owned
and operated by us, such as our existing waste-to-energy plant in Eisenhüttenstadt;

  - currency exchange rate movements;

  - the level of vertical integration between Paper and Board;

  - our ability to successfully complete ongoing and future expansion projects; and

  - our ability to achieve cost savings.

Because many of these factors are beyond our control and certain of these factors have historically been volatile, past
performance is not necessarily indicative of future performance and it is difficult to predict future performance with any
degree of certainty.

**Cyclical Nature of our Industry and Movement in Market Prices, Raw Materials and Input Costs**

_Fluctuations in Demand and Industry Capacity_

Demand for our products is generally driven by the level of economic growth and activity. Increased levels of economic
growth and activity typically result in higher per capita use of packaging materials, both with respect to transportation of
goods and consumer presentation. This increase in the use of packaging materials (including paper-based packaging
materials), in turn, results in an increase in the demand for our recycled containerboard and corrugated board products.
Because the markets for containerboard and corrugated board products in the developed economies in which we primarily
operate are generally mature, historically there has been a close correlation between general economic growth and demand
for packaging products such as corrugated containers and, therefore, for their component materials such as containerboard
and corrugated board. Accordingly, our industry is affected by economic conditions in our markets, including changes in
national, regional and local unemployment levels, shifts in consumer spending patterns, credit availability, and business
and consumer confidence. Disruptions in the overall economy and volatility in the financial markets have similarly reduced
consumer confidence and negatively affected consumer spending in the recent past, which has been harmful to our financial
position and results of operations. We have been impacted by difficult economic conditions in the past. The COVID-19
pandemic, for example, resulted in lower demand for our products in the second quarter of 2020, in particular, which led
to price reductions in the third quarter of 2020. At the same time, the price for our main raw material, recovered paper,
increased partly due to limited access to recovered paper because of reduced collection levels. Similarly, our sales decreased
significantly in 2023, compared to 2022, mainly as a result of a significant drop in the sales prices for our products due to
the weakening market environment following the Russian invasion of Ukraine. These macroeconomic developments had
a significant negative impact on our margins and results of operations in 2020 and 2023, in particular. Less developed
economies, including those in Eastern Europe, have a lower per capita consumption of packaging materials and therefore
also of containerboard and corrugated board products but also, as a result, have the potential for higher growth as per capita
consumption of packaging materials increases towards levels of developed economies.

To a lesser degree, demand for corrugated containers and their component materials, including our containerboard and
corrugated board, is affected by changes in their market prices. Significant increases in the price of corrugated containers
have, on occasion, resulted in decreased demand as end-customers elected to purchase substitute products, such as reusable
plastic containers, wooden crates or shrink-wrap.

Historically, prices for containerboard and corrugated board have tended to be cyclical. This cyclicality has resulted from
significant imbalances in supply and demand for containerboard. On the one hand, containerboard production capacity
cannot be readily adapted to reflect changing market conditions due to the high capital intensity of paper production
facilities and the long lead time between the planning and construction of a new containerboard mill. On the other hand,
significant containerboard and corrugated board price reductions and inventory growth have resulted when capacity has
exceeded demand. In the past, many leading paper manufacturers have reacted to reduced demand by taking downtimes
and by rationalizing high-cost and inefficient capacity. For example, in the third quarter of 2022, energy prices rose so
sharply in most European countries that the market price level for containerboard was not sufficient to cover these high
costs. This led to numerous shutdown measures in the industry in 2022 and 2023. While we did not initiate any marketrelated downtimes at our own facilities, we also restricted the production of containerboard during this period, as the sale
of hedged energy volumes was more profitable than the production of containerboard in this exceptional situation. Market
demand was very weak in 2023, meaning that operating rates in the containerboard industry were significantly lower than
normal, resulting in many high-priced suppliers cut their production at the lower market prices, which suggests that they
were unable to cover their costs at these prices.


-----

_Fluctuations in Raw Material Costs_

Because the primary raw material for the production of recycled containerboard is recovered paper, the price of which
tends to fluctuate, our three recycled containerboard mills (i.e., our paper machines PM1, PM2 and PM3) can experience
temporary increases and decreases in profits. Our paper mills have historically generated on average relatively high
margins, in part because we primarily sell our containerboard to our own corrugated board plants. As a result of the steady
expansion of our corrugated board production capacity over the years, internal containerboard sales to Board had increased
steadily from approximately 71% (or 83%, if we include containerboard sales to swap partners) of total containerboard
sales, by volume, of Paper in 2016 to approximately 87% (or 96%, if we include containerboard sales to swap partners) of
the total sales, by volume, of Paper in 2019. This meant that we had accomplished one of our long-standing strategic goals
and had already been operating at the top end of our long-term target corridor with regard to the level of integration between
Paper and Board and had even temporarily become a net purchaser of containerboard, i.e., the recycled containerboard
sourcing requirements of our corrugated board production within Board significantly exceeded the internal supply
capacities of Paper. With the start of production in August 2020 and subsequent ramp-up at our third and newest paper
machine (PM3) in Sandersdorf-Brehna, Germany, with an annual capacity of approximately 750,000 tons of
containerboard, the volume of our external containerboard sales significantly increased again. As a result, internal
containerboard sales to Board decreased to approximately 82% (or 92%, if we include containerboard sales to swap
partners) of total containerboard sales, by volume, of Paper in 2020, approximately 75% (or 87%, if we include
containerboard sales to swap partners) in 2021 and approximately 75% (or 85%, if we include containerboard sales to swap
partners) in 2022. Due to the further ramp-up of PM3, internal containerboard sales to Board as a percentage of total
containerboard sales, by volume, of Paper remained fairly stable at approximately 74% (or 85%, if we include
containerboard sales to swap partners) in 2023. We expect that (i) the start of commercial production in January 2023 and
ongoing ramp-up of our newest corrugated board “mega plant” (PW14) in Strykow, Poland, with an annual corrugated
board production capacity of approximately 200,000 tons, (ii) the expected start of test production in the first half of 2024
and subsequent ramp-up at our proposed corrugated board “mega plant” (PW15) in Petersberg, Germany, and (iii) our
further proposed corrugated board “mega plant” (PW16) in Cessalto, Italy alone will lead to a significant further increase
in the corrugated board production of Board, so that we expect to be operating again at the top end of our long-term target
corridor with regard to the level of integration between Paper and Board and again become a net purchaser of
containerboard in the mid-term. For more details on our expansion projects and investment program, see also“—Expansion
_Projects and Investment Program” below._

Our overall profitability is also affected by the length of time it takes us to translate price increases in raw materials and
other input costs into prices we charge for third-party sales of containerboard and corrugated board. To the extent our
containerboard is sold internally, our profitability will only be affected by the ability to recover any price increases from
third-party sales of corrugated board to our third-party customers in the packaging industry. Furthermore, to the extent that
selling prices fall, if we are unable to generate cost savings through producing products more efficiently or lower our fixed
costs, our results may be negatively affected.

An important driver of recovered paper prices is the balance of supply and demand for paper products in general as well
as collection rates of recovered paper. When the price of recovered paper increases, containerboard manufacturers attempt
to raise their prices to preserve profit margins, which generally narrow as a result of higher raw material costs. It typically
takes approximately two to three months for mills to pass on their raw material price increases to corrugated board
manufacturers. In turn, the manufacturers of corrugated board generally attempt to raise prices to recover containerboard
cost increases. It generally takes approximately two to three months for these manufacturers, including us, to pass these
increases on to the respective customers, although the extent and speed with which we are able to pass on cost increases to
our customers, if at all, can vary significantly, depending on prevailing market conditions.

In a down cycle, as recovered paper prices fall, manufacturers of paper and paper-based packaging products (including
manufacturers of containerboard and corrugated board) attempt to maintain prices. In the past, we have typically been able
to maintain our prices for two to three months in such a down cycle. As a result, the effect of price fluctuations on our mills
and corrugated board operations varies, depending on the relevant point in the industry cycle. During periods of rising
containerboard prices, our profitability can therefore be adversely affected. Conversely, during periods of declining
containerboard prices, our profitability can be positively affected.

However, our ability to pass the costs of our raw materials and other input costs on to our packaging customers depends
on a number of other factors, including the supply and demand balance for containerboard and corrugated board in a
particular region and the ability of our customers to maintain or increase prices with their own customers. We generate
almost all of our sales through purchase orders from our customers based on our price lists which we adjust in response to
market price movements and only have very few contracts with our customers which provide minimum purchase
obligations and/or pricing clauses that would allow us to automatically pass increased costs on to our customers. As a result
of these factors, there can be no guarantee that the price of recovered paper and the prices for our containerboard and
corrugated board products will always be closely correlated. Any extended mismatch between the price of recovered paper
and the market prices for our products could have a significant effect on our margins and overall profitability.


-----

The COVID-19 pandemic, for example, resulted in lower demand for our products in the second quarter of 2020, in
particular, which led to price reductions in the third quarter of 2020. At the same time, the prices for our main raw material,
recovered paper, increased in the second quarter of 2020, partly due to limited access to recovered paper because of reduced
collection levels. After a normalized market situation with price declines in the third quarter of 2020, a stronger demand
for recovered paper due to new capacity additions in the European market for containerboard, including our own paper
machine PM3, led to price increases for recovered paper starting in October 2020. Although a tighter supply situation and
strong demand caused prices for containerboard to increase again in the fourth quarter of 2020, corrugated board prices
only followed the development of containerboard prices in the first quarter of 2021 with the usual timelag. As a result, our
EBITDA Margin decreased from 25.2% in 2019 to 20.2% in 2020, and our EBITDA decreased from €223.2 million in
2019 to €178.1 million in 2020, notwithstanding strong increases in the volume of both our containerboard sales and
corrugated board sales in 2020 compared to 2019.

The price increases for recovered paper which started in October 2020 continued until April 2021. From May 2021
onwards, recovered paper prices remain largely stable, before a slight increase in September and October 2021, followed
by a decrease in November 2021 and a sideways movement in December 2021. The price increases for recycled
containerboard which had started in the fourth quarter of 2020, driven by a robust demand and the increasing recovered
paper prices, continued throughout the year 2021. Overall, prices for our recycled containerboard increased significantly
by €270 per ton between the fourth quarter of 2020 and the fourth quarter of 2021, with corrugated board prices following
this development of containerboard prices with a time lag. As a result of these developments, our EBITDA Margin
remained largely unchanged at 20.1% in 2021, compared to 20.2% in 2020, although it was significantly higher at 23.6%
in the fourth quarter of 2021. Notwithstanding our largely unchanged EBITDA Margin, our EBITDA increased
significantly from €178.1 million in 2020 to €273.2 million in 2021, due to a significant increase in sales driven by (i)
strong volume growth of both containerboard sales (due to higher production capacity following the commencement of
production at PM3 at the end of August 2020) and corrugated board sales (due to the successful ramp-up of production of
our corrugated board production site PW13 in Eisfeld, Germany following commencement of commercial production in
the first quarter of 2020), as well as (ii) the significantly higher price levels of both containerboard and corrugated board
in 2021 compared to 2020.

In the first two quarters of 2022, recovered paper prices initially continued to increase due to stable demand and higher
cargo and energy costs. However, recovered paper prices peaked in the third quarter of 2022, before falling significantly
by 52.4% over the course of the fourth quarter of 2022 due to low demand in Europe, which could not be compensated by
exports of recovered paper. Similarly the price levels for both containerboard and corrugated board continued to rise in the
first half of 2022, before falling significantly from the end of the third quarter of 2022. Notwithstanding the challenging
market environment, our EBITDA reached €412.0 million in 2022, compared to €273.2 million in 2021, as a result of
higher sales and higher margins due to the significantly higher price levels for both containerboard and corrugated board
in 2022 and supported by our energy hedges, which mitigated the significantly higher market prices for energy following
the Russian invasion of Ukraine. Following the sharp decline in recovered paper prices in 2022, recovered paper prices
rose slightly from their lows at the beginning of 2023 until the middle of the year. In the second half of 2023, the trend was
mixed, with a further slight increase towards the end of 2023. In the first four months of 2023, containerboard prices
continued the sharp downward trend of the fourth quarter of 2022. Prices stabilized in the period from May to October
2023 before taking another downward step in November 2023. Due to the very sharp change in containerboard prices at
the beginning of the year, corrugated board prices followed this trend very quickly. As a result, the time lag in this phase
was less than the usual two to three months before a change in containerboard prices was reflected in corrugated board
prices. In this very challenging market environment, EBITDA fell very quickly from the previous year's very high figure
and totalled €200.8 million for the full year 2023. See also “—Fluctuations in Energy Costs” below. Our EBITDA Margin
reached 15.2% in 2023 compared to 23.4% in 2022 and 20.1% in 2021.

_Fluctuations in Energy Costs_

Another important input for us is energy. Our production processes, in particular the production of containerboard at our
three mills, are energy intensive. We produce a significant portion of the energy required for the operation of our paper
machine PM2 ourselves, with our existing waste-to-energy plant in Eisenhüttenstadt, and we have commenced construction
of a further waste-to-energy plant (PPO2) at the site of PM3 in Sandersdorf-Brehna, to supply our paper machine PM3
with the majority of the required process heat as well as a significant portion of the required electricity. We currently expect
this second waste-to-energy plant to start operating in mid-2025. At full capacity utilization, generating the required process
heat for the operation of our paper machine PM3 would currently require an annual consumption of up to 800 GWh of
natural gas, with an average spot price for natural gas in Germany between 2015 and 2024 of approximately €35 per MWh.
In addition, PPO2 has an envisaged annual electricity production capacity of approximately 100 to 120 GWh, which we
currently need to purchase at market prices, with an average spot price for electricity in Germany between 2015 and 2024
of approximately €70 per MWh. We therefore believe we are able to generate sizable savings in energy costs from the
operation of PPO2 and a corresponding increase in EBITDA. However, our production processes are nevertheless reliant,
and will continue to be reliant, on third parties for the supply of energy. Energy costs, including costs for electricity, gas
and steam, represent our second largest purchasing cost item, accounting for 22.4% of our cost of materials in 2023,


-----

compared to 20.0% of our cost of materials in 2022, and 13.0% of our cost of materials in 2021. Market prices for energy,
in particular for electricity, oil and natural gas, have historically been volatile and have had a corresponding effect on our
production costs. The ongoing inflationary surge in 2022 and 2023 as well as the geopolitical uncertainty, partially due to
the ongoing military conflict in Ukraine and the continuing violence in Gaza and surrounding countries, may contribute to
further market unpredictability in the future and may increase the degree of volatility in the prices for energy in the future.
For example, as a result of the Russia invasion in Ukraine, energy prices reached multi-year highs in 2022. There can be
no assurances that we will not face significant increased energy costs for, or disruptions in energy supplies to our sites in
the future. Any interruption or shortage of energy supply or our inability to pass through rising energy costs could have a
material adverse effect on our business, financial condition or results of operations. As a result, we have undertaken
significant efforts in recent years to decrease our energy consumption and costs throughout our business. For further
information, see “Business—Procurement/Purchasing—Energy” and “Business—Sustainability Focus; Research and
_Development”._

The key drivers of our energy expenses have been, and will continue to be, fluctuations in the market prices for energy, the
performance of our existing waste-to-energy plant adjacent to our paper mill in Eisenhüttenstadt and the proposed further
waste-to-energy plant (PPO2) currently under construction at the site of PM3 and Sandersdorf-Brehna as well as regulatory
decisions.

Our energy costs increased significantly from €64.7 million in 2020 to €107.5 million in 2021, due to higher energy
consumption following the start-up in late August 2020 and subsequent ramp-up of our new paper machine (PM3) in
Sandersdorf-Brehna, Germany as well as higher market prices for energy. Although energy prices reached multi-year highs
in 2022 as a result of the Russian invasion of Ukraine, this only had a slight impact on our results of operation until the end
of 2022, as we had entered into long-term contracts for the majority of our energy requirements in previous years, at prices
that were significantly below market prices for energy in 2022. Nevertheless, our energy costs increased from €107.5
million in 2021 to €203.3 million in 2022. However, both as a result of weaker internal and external demand and the very
high energy spot price levels, we decided to curtail production, in particular at our newest paper machine PM3, in the third
quarter of 2022. In the first and second quarter of 2023, energy prices declined from the multi-year highs in 2022, and
energy prices remained on a similar level in the second half of 2023. Overall, energy prices were significantly lower during
2023 compared to 2022, and due to our moderate hedging levels for 2023, we benefited from the lower spot market prices
in 2023. As a result, our energy costs decreased from €203.3 million in 2022 to €179.0 million in 2023.

Any extended shutdowns of our waste-to-energy plants may also have a negative impact on our results of operations. For
example, shortly after our existing waste-to-energy plant in Eisenhüttenstadt was put back into operation following a
regular, scheduled maintenance shutdown, an operator error caused blockages inside the plant, which required a further
unplanned shutdown of the plant for a period of about three weeks in October 2023 to clear the blockages. This unplanned
shutdown resulted in approximately €5.7 million in items of exceptional size or incidence, including approximately
€0.3 million in additional maintenance expenses and €5.4 million in lost sales and additional production costs.

In addition to fluctuations in the market prices for energy and the performance of our waste-to-energy plants, in Germany,
our core market where all three of our mills are located, energy costs have further been strongly impacted by regulatory
decisions related to the so-called “Energiewende”, a significant shift in government policy following the nuclear accident
in Fukushima, Japan in 2011. This German energy policy focuses on promoting the development of renewable energy
sources and, among other developments, has already resulted in the complete cessation of the production of nuclear power
in Germany. To mitigate the impact of the resulting significant increases in electricity prices for energy-intensive industries,
the German government adopted rules that provide for various businesses, including us, to be reimbursed for certain energyrelated taxes and/or infrastructure investment surcharges necessary for the implementation of the “Energiewende”.
However, such rules have not only been subject to challenges in German courts and EU scrutiny as potentially illegal
subsidies, but also continue to be the subject of political scrutiny by various interest groups. There is no guarantee that they
will not change again or that we will continue to be able to benefit from current accommodations, reimbursement rules
and/or energy tax refund schemes.

As a result of the significant increases in production volumes in recent years, in particular following the start-up in late
August 2020 and subsequent ramp-up of our new paper machine (PM3) in Sandersdorf-Brehna, Germany, our total energy
consumption has increased significantly in recent years. However, at the same time, our energy consumption per ton of
output has decreased for a variety of reasons, including (i) our efforts to reduce energy consumption, (ii) the optimization
of our energy procurement processes and (iii) the optimization of the operating costs of our existing waste-to-energy plan
in Eisenhüttenstadt. Specifically, energy consumption per ton of output of Paper decreased by 5.4% between 2012 and
2022, while energy consumption per ton of output of Board decreased by 14.6% during the same period. In addition, we
were able to reduce energy costs through the full utilization of all available accommodations, credits and refunds under
applicable energy laws and regulations. For more information about our energy management efforts, see “—Sustainability
_Focus; Research and Development”._


-----

_Fluctuations in Freight/Logistics Costs_

Our production operations require us to coordinate and monitor complex logistical processes between each step of our
internal value chain and our production processes to ensure the efficient flow of materials and products. This includes the
shipment of large rolls of containerboard from our three paper mills in Germany to our twelve corrugated board plants in
the Czech Republic, France, Germany, Italy, Poland and the United Kingdom as well as the shipment of our finished
corrugated board to our customers in the packaging industry (box plants). We meet our freight and logistics requirements
mainly through the use of external logistics companies and, to a much lesser extent, our own fleet of currently 59 trucks.
Due to the relatively large size and weight of our products compared to value, freight and logistics expenses play an
important role in our business, and fluctuations in freight prices can have a significant impact on our profitability.

**Currency Fluctuations**

Given the growing geographic spread of our operations, we are increasingly exposed to currency exchange rate fluctuations.
For example, the United Kingdom, the Czech Republic and Poland do not use the euro as their national currency. During
the year ended December 31, 2023, 18%, 10% and 4% of our total sales derived from sales in Polish zloty, British pound
and Czech koruna, respectively. We expect the percentage of our total sales derived in Polish zloty, in particular, to further
increase as a result of the start of commercial production in January 2023 and ongoing ramp-up of our newest corrugated
board “mega plant” (PW14) in Strykow, Poland.

As a result, fluctuations in the value of local currencies against the euro have had, and may have in the future, a significant
effect on our operations and on our reported results in euro and the comparability of our performance between financial
periods can be significantly affected by fluctuations in local currencies against the euro. We have implemented foreign
currency risk management in order to monitor our foreign currency risk and to enable us to consider taking action if we
decide to do so, but there is no assurance that such measures will be effective.

The relative strength or weakness of the U.S. dollar is also important for the European containerboard industry, because
exports from the European market influence the balance of supply and demand and the price development of containerboard
in Europe. Movements in the U.S. dollar exchange rate may also have an effect on trading, because a strong U.S. dollar
tends to make U.S. dollar exports less competitive, while a weak euro may create export opportunities for European
containerboard producers, which can reduce containerboard supplies in the European market and promote price stability.
Conversely, a weak U.S. dollar over a sustained period has historically resulted in lower (U.S. dollar-denominated) exports
by European containerboard manufacturers with a negative (for our business) effect on the supply and demand balance and
an immediate effect on the pricing of containerboard in Europe. In addition, a weak U.S. dollar over a sustained period has,
in the past, also resulted in lower sales by other European manufacturers who ship products in corrugated packaging,
resulting in lower European demand for corrugated packaging and, therefore, lower demand for our containerboard and
corrugated board. A weak U.S. dollar may also result in additional competition in the European market from U.S.
manufacturers that have an incentive to sell more products in Europe, due to increased European demand for the relatively
lower-priced U.S. goods over higher-priced European goods.

**Significant Synergies through High Degree of Vertical Integration between Paper and Board**

In 2023, containerboard produced by Paper accounted for approximately 76% of the containerboard, by volume, used by
our corrugated board production within Board. As a result of the steady expansion of our corrugated board production
capacity over the years, internal containerboard sales to Board had increased steadily from approximately 71% (or 83%, if
we include containerboard sales to swap partners) of total containerboard sales, by volume, of Paper in 2016 to
approximately 87% (or 96%, if we include containerboard sales to swap partners) of total containerboard sales, by volume,
of Paper in 2019. This meant that we had accomplished one of our long-standing strategic goals and had already been
operating at the top end of our long-term target corridor with regard to the level of integration between Paper and Board
and had even temporarily become a net purchaser of containerboard, i.e., the recycled containerboard sourcing requirements
of our corrugated board production within Board significantly exceeded the internal supply capacities of Paper. With the
start of production in August 2020 and subsequent ramp-up at our third and newest paper machine (PM3) in SandersdorfBrehna, Germany, with an annual capacity of approximately 750,000 tons of containerboard, the volume of our external
containerboard sales significantly increased again. As a result, internal containerboard sales to Board decreased to
approximately 82% (or 92%, if we include containerboard sales to swap partners) of total containerboard sales, by volume,
of Paper in 2020, approximately 75% (or 87%, if we include containerboard sales to swap partners) in 2021 and
approximately 75% (or 85%, if we include containerboard sales to swap partners) in 2022. Due to the further ramp-up of
PM3, internal containerboard sales to Board as a percentage of total containerboard sales, by volume, of Paper remained
fairly stable at approximately 74% (or 85%, if we include containerboard sales to swap partners) in 2023. We expect that
(i) the start of commercial production in January 2023 and ongoing ramp-up of our newest corrugated board “mega plant”
(PW14) in Strykow, Poland, with an annual corrugated board production capacity of approximately 200,000 tons, (ii) the
expected start of test production in the first half of 2024 and subsequent ramp-up at our proposed corrugated board “mega
plant” (PW15) in Petersberg, Germany, and (iii) our further proposed corrugated board “mega plant” (PW16) in Cessalto,


-----

Italy alone will lead to a significant further increase in the corrugated board production of Board, so that we will again be
operating at the top end of our long-term target corridor with regard to the level of integration between Paper and Board
and again become a net purchaser of containerboard in the mid-term. For more details on our expansion projects and
investment program, see also“—Expansion Projects and Investment Program” below.

With an envisaged total annual containerboard capacity of approximately 1,850,000 tons, Paper produced approximately
1,574,000 tons and 1,607,000 tons of containerboard in 2023 and 2021, respectively. In 2023, approximately
1,153,000 tons were sold internally to Board (2021: 1,187,000 tons of internal containerboard sales), and a further
approximately 163,000 tons were sold pursuant to swap agreements with other containerboard producers (2021:
194,000 tons of sales to swap partners), which allow us to reduce transportation costs, optimize our production program
and swap internally produced containerboard for certain containerboard grades we do not produce in sufficient quantities,
such as kraftliner. The remaining approximately 241,000 tons of containerboard we sold in 2023 were sold externally
(2021: approximately 206,000 tons of external containerboard sales, excluding sales to swap partners). With a total annual
corrugated board production capacity of approximately 1,815,000 tons (including 200,000 tons of capacity of our new
corrugated board “mega plant” (PW14) in Strykow, Poland, which commenced commercial production in January 2023,
but excluding a further 200,000 tons of capacity of our proposed corrugated board “mega plant” (PW15) in Petersberg,
Germany, which is expected to commence production in the second quarter of 2024 (2021: total annual corrugated board
production capacity of approximately 1,615,000 tons), Board produced approximately 1,494,000 tons of containerboard in
2023, compared to approximately 1,504,000 tons of corrugated board in 2021. We believe that a high degree of vertical
integration and making full use of the ability to internally source consistently high-quality containerboard in a cost-efficient
and highly flexible manner creates significant synergies for our business. At the same time, we believe that the high share
of internal containerboard sales may help us stabilize or improve our overall Group margins by reducing our exposure to
lower or more volatile margins (compared to corrugated board margins) of certain external containerboard sales. Our
customers benefit from our integrated approach through short lead times, just-in-time delivery, consistently high quality as
well as the possibility for online ordering and tracking options. The steady increase in the degree of vertical integration
between Paper and Board over the last few years has also been allowing us to further optimize our internal logistics and
supply chain.

**Expansion Projects and Investment Program**

To maintain and further strengthen our position as a leading, low-cost corrugated board producer in Europe in the longterm and to allow us to successfully meet ongoing and expected future market growth and the requirements of our customers
with regard to supply certainty and product quality, we intend to continue to make prudent and controlled investments to
further expand and improve the efficiency of our production facilities as part of our long-term “Two Twentyfive” strategy.
In addition to further capacity expansion, our “Two Twentyfive” strategy, among other things, also contemplates a gradual
technological transition and generation change away from the use of corrugators with a trim width of 2.5m, which are
installed and currently in use at some of our older corrugated board production sites, to the use of more modern corrugators
with trim widths of 2.8m or 3.3m at most of our corrugated board production sites.

With the start of production in August 2020 and subsequent ramp-up at our third and newest paper machine (PM3) in
Sandersdorf-Brehna, Germany, we became a significant net seller of containerboard again. In the short- to mid-term, we
therefore intend to continue to focus our investment activities on further expanding our corrugated board production
capacity to be able to seize what we believe are numerous further market opportunities for profitable growth, similar to
those that led to the successful establishment of six new corrugated board plants (PW09, PW10, PW11, PW12, PW13 and
PW14) in Plössberg (Germany), Trzcinica (Poland), Drizzona (Italy), Ellesmere Port (United Kingdom), Eisfeld
(Germany) and Strykow (Poland) since 2015. We expect that (i) the start of commercial production in January 2023 and
ongoing ramp-up of our newest corrugated board “mega plant” (PW14) in Strykow, Poland, with an annual corrugated
board production capacity of approximately 200,000 tons, (ii) the expected start of production in the second quarter of
2024 and subsequent ramp-up at our proposed corrugated board “mega plant” (PW15) in Petersberg, Germany, and (iii)
our further proposed corrugated board “mega plant” (PW16) in Cessalto, Italy will lead to a further increase in the
corrugated board production of Board, so that we will again be operating at the top end of our long-term target corridor
with regard to the level of integration between Paper and Board and again become a net purchaser of containerboard in the
mid-term. With the proposed additional corrugated board plants (PW15 and PW16) in Petersberg, Germany and Drizzona,
Italy, we expect our annual corrugated board production capacity to increase from currently approximately 1,815,000 tons
to approximately 2,215,000 tons.

In continuation of our organic growth strategy, we intend to achieve further growth by pursuing further expansion
opportunities via greenfield projects. However, as with our corrugated board production sites (PW03 in Burg, (PW05) in
Schüttorf, (PW06) in Offenbach a.d. Queich and (PW09) in Plössberg, Germany, our corrugated board production sites
(PW10) in Trzcinica and (PW14) in Strykow, Poland, our production site (PW11) in Drizzona, Italy and our production
site (PW12 ) in Ellesmere Port, United Kingdom, we are also establishing our proposed new corrugated board production
site (PW15) in Petersberg, Germany as a packaging park project in immediate proximity to the existing packaging plant of
a customer, German packaging specialist G&G Preißer, which allows us to supply this long-standing customer and partner


-----

largely without freight and other freight expenses. Our latest corrugated board project (PW16) in Cessalto, Italy will also
be established in immediate vicinity to an existing packaging customer as a packaging park.

While we have historically pursued a pure greenfield growth strategy, including the ten packaging park projects (PW03,
PW05, two packaging park customers at PW06, PW09, PW10, PW11, PW12, PW13 and PW14) and the proposed new
corrugated board production sites (PW15 and PW16) in Germany and Italy, we are also evaluating and will continue to
evaluate opportunities to find partners to leverage the benefits of a packaging park and that would enrich our existing
network of production sites, advance our goal of further increasing our corrugated board production capacity and meet the
other internal investment and financing criteria described above. In addition, in order to maintain and/or strengthen our
relationships with certain large and long-standing customers or in response to opportunities to establish relationships with
significant new customers, we will consider additional packaging park projects whereby we would establish corrugated
board production sites at or in proximity to the packaging plants of the relevant customers. We currently expect to make
total investments of approximately €246 million into the two proposed new corrugated board production sites (PW15 and
PW16) in Germany and Italy. With an expected combined annual incremental corrugated board production capacity for
PW15 and PW16 of approximately 400,000 tons of corrugated board, an average net selling price per ton of corrugated
board of €756.1 per ton in 2023 and historic EBITDA margins for Board in the high single digit to low double digit range,
we believe PW15 and PW16 to be able to make a sizable contribution to EBITDA following completion of both projects.
Historically, our new corrugated board production sites have typically achieved a capacity utilization level of around 90%
within 3 to 5 years of start of operation.

In the first quarter of 2023, we started construction of a new waste-to-energy plant (PPO2) next to PM3 in SandersdorfBrehna, to supply our newest paper machine with the required process steam as well as electricity. We currently expect to
make total investments of approximately €190 million, with a target completion date towards mid-2025.

As part of our long-term planning, we finally seized the opportunity to secure a currently disused, traditional paper site in
Stockstadt near Aschaffenburg, Germany from Sappi. We signed the purchase agreement in September 2023 and expect
the acquisition to close towards the end of April 2024. In October 2023, we made a downpayment, and in May 2024, we
will be required to pay the bulk of the purchase price, the amount of which we have agreed to keep confidential. We believe
that the site offers us a rare option to develop a further potential paper mill project in the future. Our intention is to develop
a further circular economy concept for the site step-by-step so that we can use a closed material loop to manufacture
containerboard in a sustainable and innovative way and thus continue our growth strategy in the long run. Although we do
not currently plan to implement a further paper machine project in the short-term and do not currently expect to commence
production at any such potential further paper mill before the end of the decade, we believe that our limited investment to
secure the new site in Stockstadt demonstrates our advantage of being able to make long-term investment decisions as a
family-owned business.

Even successful expansion (or acquisition) projects can have a negative impact on our profitability in the short-term. For
example, our reduced profitability between 2009 and 2010 following the global financial and economic crisis coincided
with the launch of production at our corrugated board production sites in Strykow, Poland (PW7) and Ellesmere Port,
United Kingdom (PW8) and at our paper mill in Eisenhüttenstadt, Germany (PM2), which involved significant start-up
and ramp-up costs. Similarly, our reduced profitability in 2020, the first year of the COVID-19 pandemic, coincided with
the ramp-up of our corrugated board production site (PW13) in Eisfeld, Germany and the launch of production and
subsequent ramp-up at our paper mill in Sandersdorf-Brehna, Germany (PM3), which involved significant start-up and
ramp-up costs. In each case, the related costs were largely expected and are normal in our industry, but their timing put
further pressure on our profitability. In addition, even in a positive market environment, it typically takes two to three years
from the launch of a new corrugated board production site until the production site is fully utilized. For example, we
launched our corrugated board production site in Eisfeld, Germany (PW13) in November 2019, but the site only completed
its ramp-up phase in 2021 and therefore, did not operate at a three-shift capacity for an entire year until 2021. Our newest
corrugated board “mega plant” (PW14) in Strykow, Poland commenced commercial production in January 2023 and we
do not expect it to complete its ramp-up phase and to operate at a full, three-shift capacity until sometime in 2025. We
expect our proposed new corrugated board production site (PW15) in Petersberg, Germany and our proposed further
corrugated board “mega plant” (PW16) in Cessalto, Italy with a combined expected total annual incremental corrugated
board production capacity of 400,000 tons, to also undergo ramp-up phases of different durations with a corresponding
impact on our result of operations. Moreover, the start-up and ramp-up costs and short- to mid-term impact on our
profitability of our latest paper machine project (PM3) will be proportionately higher, due to the much larger size, higher
level of complexity and longer implementation timeframe of such a project, compared to the establishment of a new
corrugated board production site. Even though our newest paper mill in Sandersdorf-Brehna (PM3) commenced operations
in August 2020, it has still not completed its initial ramp-up phase, and we are still continuing our efforts to optimize our
operations at this newest mill, which involves not only the optimization of the performance of PM3, but also the
optimization of connected processes, including the operation of the closed cycle water treatment system at PM3 and the
proposed further waste-to-energy plant that is currently under construction in Sandersdorf-Brehna. For more information
about the risks associated with the integration of potential expansion projects and acquisitions, see also “Risk Factors—

_Risks Related to our Industry and our Business—The costs and difficulties of integrating complementary businesses_

**Continuous Improvement Program**

As described above, we operate in a cyclical industry where the price of our containerboard and corrugated board as well
as recovered paper, our primary raw material, is subject to cyclical fluctuations. Other major cost items, such as personnel
expenses, are the subject of annual increases, and the costs of energy and freight, which are also significant expenses, have
partly trended upwards. In order to maintain profitability throughout the economic cycle, we have implemented a
comprehensive profitability improvement program (the “Continuous Improvement Program”) to ensure the long-term
success of our Group. Our Continuous Improvement Program focuses on (i) improving the effectiveness of our sales and
marketing activities, (ii) optimizing (i.e., minimizing) our variable costs and (iii) stabilizing our specific fixed costs in order
to achieve sales excellence and maintain our position as one of the cost leaders in the recycled containerboard market.

Since 2012, our main focus in connection with our goal of achieving sales excellence has been on (i) growing our external
sales in excess of the general growth in market volumes (and thereby increasing our market share), (ii) maximizing the
impact of the introduction of our “next generation” products into the market, and (iii) optimizing our sales portfolio. As
part of our efforts to optimize our variable costs, we have focused on (i) reducing our consumption of raw materials,
(ii) optimizing our energy consumption and energy costs and (iii) reducing the purchase prices of our key production
factors, such as recovered paper, starch and freight services. Our continued ability to implement these and other efficiency
improvement projects successfully may have a significant impact on our profitability. For more information about our past
and ongoing efforts to ensure the sustainability of our business and to maintain our position as a cost leader, see also “—
_Significant Synergies through High Degree of Vertical Integration between Paper and Board” and “Business—_
_Sustainability Focus; Research and Development”._

**KEY INCOME STATEMENT ITEMS**

The following is a description of certain line items in our consolidated income statement.

**Sales**

Sales primarily include income derived from the sale of corrugated board and external sales of containerboard. We report
sales as sales in Germany and sales abroad (by destination), respectively, based on the country in which our customer is
located. Other sales primarily include freight sales of Logistics, for example, when we hire out trucks from our own fleet
to avoid empty trips or to make use of opportunities in the freight market.

**Increase/(decrease) in finished goods and work in process**

Increase/(decrease) in finished goods and work in process records the increase/(decrease) in finished goods and work in
process at manufacturing cost. The manufacturing costs include direct material and labor costs as well as material and
production overheads allocated proportionally on the assumption of normal utilization of production capacity.

**Other own work capitalized**

Other own work capitalized mainly relates to capitalized personnel expenses in connection with our ongoing investment
projects.

**Other operating income**

Other operating income consists of all income from ordinary business activities not already recognized under other income
items. Other operating income includes, among other things, income from investment subsidies, income from other periods,
income from the release of provisions, refunds of energy tax, income from insurance refunds from damage events, income
from reduction of bad debt allowance, and exchange rate gains.

**Cost of materials**

Cost of materials consists of costs of raw materials, consumables and supplies and purchased goods such as recovered
paper, externally purchased containerboard, costs of chemicals, costs for auxiliary materials as well as pallet costs. It also
includes costs of purchased services, including energy (i.e., for electricity, gas and steam), costs of waste disposal and costs
for freight brokerage at Logistics.


-----

**Personnel expenses**

Personnel expenses include all expenses for wages and salaries (including bonuses) and other employment benefits,
contributions to pension plans and social security contributions. Personnel expenses also include the costs of hiring new
personnel and training costs.

**Amortization and depreciation of fixed intangible and tangible assets and exceptional write downs on current assets**

We incur expense for depreciation and amortization of property, plant and equipment and intangible fixed assets as a result
of both scheduled depreciation and impairment losses on these assets. Depreciation and amortization are usually charged
on a straight-line basis over the expected useful life of the assets.

**Other operating expenses**

Other operating expenses primarily include freight expenses, expenses from exchange rate differences, expenses from other
periods, maintenance and repair expenses, insurance and additional expenses, personnel-related expenses, rental and
leasing expenses, vehicle expenses (excl. rental and leasing expenses), legal and consulting fees and other expenses
(including extraordinary expenses).

**Depreciation on financial assets and of securities held as current assets**

Depreciation on financial assets and of securities held as current assets include impairment losses on financial assets and
marketable securities.

**Interest income/(expenses), net**

Interest income/(expenses), net includes other interest and similar income as well as interest and similar expenses. Interest
and similar expenses primarily include interest expense and other financing costs related to long-term loans, short-term
bank liabilities as well as bank and bank guarantee provisions.

**Taxes**

Taxes comprise trade taxes, corporate taxes, foreign taxes, deferred taxes as well as other taxes, such as taxes on substance
(mainly real estate taxes as well as motor vehicle taxes).

**_Sales_**

Total sales decreased by €439.2 million, or 25.0%, from €1,759.2 million in 2022 to €1,320.0 million in 2023. This decrease
was mainly attributable to lower price levels which negatively impacted our sales in 2023 by €463.7 million and outweighed
a positive contribution of €66.9 million of higher sales volumes compared to 2022. Total corrugated board sales decreased
by €336.0 million, or 22.8%, from €1,472.6 million in 2022 to €1,136.7 million in 2023. Corrugated board sales volumes
increased by approximately 62,000 tons, from approximately 1,432,000 tons in 2022 to approximately 1,494,000 tons in
2023. The increased sales volume was mainly attributable to the ramp-up of our newest corrugated board plant (PW14) in
Strykow, Poland, following the start of commercial production in January 2023, and volume increases in Italy and the
United Kingdom. However, the average price per ton of corrugated board in 2023 was significantly below the average
price of 2022 (-24%). At the same time, our total containerboard sales volume decreased slightly by approximately 5,000
tons, or 0.3%, from approximately 1,568,000 tons in 2022 to approximately 1,563,000 tons in 2023. External sales volume
of containerboard increased by approximately 8,000 tons, or 2%, from approximately 395,000 tons in 2022 to
approximately 403,000 tons in 2023. The average price per ton for externally sold containerboard in 2023 was also
significantly below the average price in 2022 (-39%), which also had a negative impact on our total sales in 2023. See also
“—Key Factors Affecting our Results of Operations—Cyclical Nature of our Industry and Movement in Market Prices,
_Raw Materials and Input Costs—Fluctuations in Demand and Industry Capacity” and “—Key Factors Affecting our Results_
_of Operations—Cyclical Nature of our Industry and Movement in Market Prices, Raw Materials and Input Costs—_

**_Sales_**

Total sales increased significantly by €402.2 million, or 29.6%, from €1,357.0 million in 2021 to €1,759.2 million in 2022.
This increase in sales was attributable to a slight decrease in sales volume with a negative impact of €54.4 million,
outweighed by the significantly higher prices for both corrugated board and containerboard products with a positive
contribution of €436.4 million compared to 2021. Corrugated board sales increased by €329.4 million, or 28.8%, in 2022
compared to 2021, significantly in excess of general market growth. Corrugated board sales volumes decreased by
approximately 72,000 tons, from approximately 1,504,000 tons in 2021 to approximately 1,432,000 tons in 2022. The
reduced sales volume was attributable to lower order intakes in most markets mainly as a consequence of the subdued
market environment. Furthermore, the lower order intake led to lower utilization rates of our corrugated board plants.
Additionally, the market environment was more challenging in 2022 than in 2021. Our total containerboard sales volume
decreased slightly by approximately 19,000 tons, or 1.2%, from approximately 1,587,000 tons in 2021 to approximately
1,568,000 tons in 2022. External sales volume of containerboard decreased by approximately 5,000 tons, or 1.3%, from
approximately 400,000 tons in 2021 to approximately 395,000 tons in 2022. In response to weaker internal and external
demand as well as the very high energy spot price levels in 2022 as a result of the Russian invasion of Ukraine, we curtailed
production, especially at our newest paper machine PM3 in the third quarter of 2022. As a result, the average level of
integration between Paper and Board, including swap agreements, decreased from 87% in 2021 to 85% in 2022. The
average price per ton for externally sold containerboard in 2022 was significantly above the average price in 2021 (+34%).
While in 2021 price increases for containerboard were mainly driven by strong demand, prices for containerboard continued
to rise steadily in the first half of 2022 due to the strong increases in energy and raw material costs. Increasingly high stocks
of containerboard in the industry and lower raw material costs led to a subsequent drop in prices in the second half of 2022.
At the same time, the average price of corrugated board in 2022 was significantly above the average price of 2021 (+35.0%).
Following the containerboard market, prices for corrugated board rose continuously in the first half of 2022, with necessary
price reductions to limit a decline in sales volume and support sales performance in the second half of 2022. See also “—
_Key Factors Affecting our Results of Operations——Cyclical Nature of our Industry and Movement in Market Prices, Raw_
_Materials and Input Costs—Fluctuations in Raw Material Costs” above._

higher costs for starch. The average costs per ton for our recovered paper purchases in 2022 were slightly higher (+3.5%)
compared to 2021. The cost of purchased services also increased by €102.0 million, or 65.5%, from €155.8 million in 2021
to €257.8 million in 2022. Costs for freight brokerage at Logistics increased by €4.2 million, or 15.3% from €27.1 million
in 2021 to €31.3 million in 2022.

**LIQUIDITY AND CAPITAL RESOURCES**

**Overview**

Our primary sources of financing are cash generated from our operating activities and external financings, including
drawings under the Senior Secured Facilities Agreements and proceeds from the issuance of the Notes. As of the date of
this offering memorandum, we have undrawn capacity of €200 million under the Senior Secured Revolving Credit Facility
Agreement. Our cash requirements consist mainly of debt and tax servicing requirements, the purchase of raw materials,
energy and freight, working capital, personnel expenses and capital expenditures, including in relation to the planned
expansion projects. See “—Key Factors Affecting our Results of Operations—Expansion Projects and Investment
_Program”._

As of December 31, 2023, we had Total Financial Debt (calculated as bank loans plus bonds, minus other securities, i.e.,
Existing Notes we have repurchased and hold on balance sheet) of €762.6 million compared to €813.9 million as of
December 31, 2022 and €874.9 million as of December 31, 2021. As of December 31, 2023, we had cash-in-hand, bank
balances in the amount of €130.5 million and Net Financial Debt of €632.1 million (calculated as Total Financial Debt less
cash-in-hand, bank balances).

Our ability to generate cash from our operating activities depends on our future operating performance, which is in turn
dependent, to some extent, on general economic, financial, competitive, market, regulatory and other factors, many of
which are beyond our control, as well as other factors discussed under “Risk Factors”. In addition, our ability to draw under
the Senior Secured Revolving Credit Facility Agreement will only be available if, among other things, we meet the financial
covenant set out therein. See “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—Senior Secured Revolving Credit Facility
_Agreement”._

Although we believe that our expected cash flows from operating activities, capacity under the Senior Secured Revolving
Credit Facility Agreement and cash-in-hand as well as bank balances will be adequate to meet our anticipated liquidity and
debt service needs, we cannot assure you that our business will generate sufficient cash flows from operating activities or
that future debt and equity financing will be available to us in an amount sufficient to enable us to pay our debts when due,
including the Notes, or to fund our other liquidity needs.


-----

If our future cash flows from operating activities and other capital resources (including borrowings under our current or
any future credit facility) are insufficient to pay our obligations as they mature or to fund our liquidity needs, we may be
forced to:

  - reduce or delay our business activities and capital expenditures;

  - sell certain of our assets;

  - obtain additional debt or equity financing; or

  - restructure or refinance all or a portion of our debt, including the Notes, on or before maturity.

We cannot assure you that we would be able to accomplish any of these alternatives on a timely basis or on satisfactory
terms, if at all. In addition, the terms of the Senior Secured Facilities, the Notes and any future debt may limit our ability
to pursue any of these alternatives.

_Cash flow from operating activities_

In 2023, our cash flow from operating activities decreased by €146.1 million from €365.3 million in 2022 to €219.2 million
in 2023. This decrease in our cash flow from operating activities was primarily attributable to the lower consolidated net
income in 2023 and higher cash outflows for income taxes paid. Contrary effects resulted from a €65.4 million balance
sheet decrease in Trade Working Capital from €268.7 million as at December 31, 2022 to €203.3 million as at December
31, 2023.

In 2022, our cash flow from operating activities increased by €209.4 million from €155.9 million in 2021 to €365.3 million
in 2022. The increase in our cash flow from operating activities was primarily attributable to our significantly improved
EBITDA as a result of our strong operational performance. Contrary effects resulted from a €49.6 million balance sheet
increase in our Trade Working Capital, from €219.1 million as at December 31, 2021 to €268.7 million as at December 31,
2022, as described in more detail below.


-----

Our cash flow from operating activities is significantly affected by changes in our net working capital. As a result, our cash
flow from operating activities can be significantly affected by changes in raw material prices or an increase or decrease of
sales volumes as well as payment terms, as those factors affect the amount of inventories, trade receivables and trade
payables. The following table sets forth our net working capital as of the dates indicated:

We record a liability under trade payables only if we have received the related supplier invoice by the relevant balance
sheet date and provided that all other prerequisites for the recognition as a liability have been met. We record liabilities
related to goods or services we have received during the relevant period, but for which we have not yet received an invoice,
under other provisions on our balance sheet. These provisions for outstanding invoices amounted to €46.7 million, €62.7
million and €62.1 million as of December 31, 2021, 2022 and 2023, respectively.

In 2023, our Trade Working Capital decreased by €65.4 million, or 24.3%, from €268.7 million as of December 31, 2022
to €203.3 million as of December 31, 2023. The decrease in our Trade Working Capital is attributable to (i) a significant
decrease in our trade receivables, (ii) a decrease in our inventories and (iii) an increase in our trade payables. Trade
receivables decreased by €44.0 million, or 24.9%, from €177.1 million as of December 31, 2022 to €133.1 million as of
December, 2023, mainly due to lower sales based on lower sales prices in December 2023. The decrease of €10.8 million,
or 6.0%, in inventories from €181.4 million as of December 31, 2022 to €170.6 million as of December 31, 2023 was
mainly driven by a decrease of the price levels for containerboard and corrugated board in 2023 and therefore a lower
valuation of our work in progress as well as a lower stock of containerboard. This decrease was partly compensated for by
higher raw materials, consumables and supplies as a result of a higher number of spare parts. At the same time, the amount
of trade payables increased by €10.5 million, or 11.7%, from €89.8 million as of December 31, 2022 to €100.3 million as
of December 31, 2023. This increase was primarily related to our ongoing expansion projects and year end effects.

In 2022, our Trade Working Capital increased significantly by €49.6 million, or 22.7%, from €219.1 million as of
December 31, 2021 to €268.7 million as of December 31, 2022. The increase in our Trade Working Capital is attributable
to (i) an increase in our trade receivables, (ii) an significant increase in our inventories and (iii) a decrease in our trade
payables. Trade receivables increased by €9.6 million, or 5.7%, from €167.5 million as of December 31, 2021 to €177.1
million as of December 31, 2022 mainly due to higher sales and year-end effects as at December 31, 2021. The significant
increase of €18.8 million, or 11.5%, in inventories from €162.6 million as of December 31, 2021 to €181.4 million as of
December 31, 2022 was mainly driven by an increase of the price levels for containerboard and corrugated board in 2022
and therefore a higher valuation of our finished goods. Furthermore, raw materials, consumables and supplies increased as
a result of a higher number of spare parts. At the same time, the amount of trade payables decreased by €21.3 million, or
19.2%, from €111.1 million as of December 31, 2021 to €89.8 million as of December 31, 2022 mainly due to lower price
levels for purchased raw materials, especially recovered paper, as well as year-end effects.

_Cash flow from investing activities_

Cash flows from investing activities generally consist of cash outflows for investments in tangible and intangible fixed
assets as well as cash inflows from the disposal of fixed assets as well as interest received concerning financial assets and
cash in hand.

In 2023, our cash outflow from investing activities increased slightly by €3.9 million, or 2.3%, from €165.1 million in 2022
to €169.0 million in 2023. These cash outflows were mainly attributable to investments in our corrugated board plant
projects in Strykow, Poland (PW14), Petersberg, Germany (PW15) and Cessalto, Italy (PW16) and in the further waste-toenergy plant (PPO2) in Sandersdorf-Brehna, Germany. In addition to these major projects, several medium-sized and
smaller investments in different plants were also included as part of our Capital Expenditures, as they are expected to lead
to an improvement in our operating performance.


-----

In 2022, our cash outflows from investing activities significantly increased by €53.0 million, or 47.3%, from €112.1 million
in 2021 to €165.1 million in 2022. These cash outflows were mainly attributable to investments in our corrugated board
plant projects in Strykow, Poland (PW14), Petersberg, Germany (PW15) and Cessalto, Italy (PW16) and in the proposed
further waste-to-energy plant (PPO2) in Sandersdorf-Brehna, Germany. In addition to these major projects, several
medium-sized and smaller investments in different plants were also included as part of our Capital Expenditures, as they
are expected to lead to an improvement in our operating performance. Cash outflows from investing activities in 2022
further included €28.4 million in outflows payments to acquire financial assets as part of financial short-term planning
related to open market purchases of the Existing Notes.

_Free Cash Flow_

We define Free Cash Flow as cash flow from operating activities less cash outflows from investing activities. Free Cash
Flow comprises the cash surplus or deficit after expenditure on investments and taxes but before net cash used in/provided
by financing activities, and before taking into account cash proceeds and payments relating to shareholders’ equity and


-----

financial liabilities. The reasons for changes in the Free Cash Flow are therefore the same as explained above. In 2023, our
Free Cash Flow decreased by €150.0 million, from a cash inflow of €200.2 million in 2022 to a cash inflow of €50.2 million
in 2023. In 2022, our Free Cash Flow increased significantly by €156.4 million, from a cash inflow of €43.8 million in
2021 to a cash inflow of €200.2 million in 2022.

**Liquidity management**

While we intend to primarily meet our liquidity requirements with cash-in-hand and bank balances as well as cash generated
from our operating activities, we expect to have sufficient capacity available under the Senior Secured Revolving Credit
Facility Agreement to be able to meet any additional operating requirements. As of the date of this offering memorandum,
we have undrawn capacity of €200.0 million under the Senior Secured Revolving Credit Facility Agreement.

To manage our liquidity, we maintain a largely centralized cash management system, which includes all our subsidiaries.
In particular, liquidity plans are prepared with the Group budget on a monthly rolling period for the upcoming 12 months
in which the expected cash receipts and payments for the specified time period are set off against each other.
